Violation_Type: Failure to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred by failing to consider the qualitative test of residency in addition to the physical presence test
Application_Facts: Dedaj was found short of the required 1,095 days of physical presence but had established ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; original decision set aside
Court_Ruling: Federal Court granted the appeal due to legal error in omitting the qualitative residency test
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge focused only on post-application actions and did not assess Dedaj's Canadian ties
Grounds_for_Claim: Legal error in applying only the physical presence test without considering qualitative residency factors
Legal_Standard: Both physical presence and qualitative residency tests must be applied under the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Applicant's ties to Canada, including family, employment, and intent
Procedural_Issue: Failure to apply both statutory tests in citizenship assessment
Evidence_Used: Evidence of Dedaj's connections to Canada, such as familial and community ties
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of the Citizenship Act relating to residency requirement (1,095 days)
Application_Basis: Permanent resident applying for Canadian citizenship
Evidence_Assessed: Post-application conduct and presence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Allowance of appeal and remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Both physical and qualitative tests for residency must be satisfied under the Citizenship Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis regarding qualitative residency despite sufficient evidence of Canadian ties
Outcome: Appeal granted; case remanded to a different citizenship judge for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to incomplete legal analysis
Cause_Description: Dedaj's application was dismissed based solely on insufficient physical presence days, without evaluating his overall connection to Canada
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient consideration of non-physical residency indicators
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirements under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Issues: Overemphasis on quantitative presence; neglect of qualitative evidence
Residency_Compliance: Partially compliant – met qualitative aspects but fell short on physical days
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete – failed to weigh all relevant factors for residency
Decision_Rationale: The judge committed a reviewable error by not applying the qualitative test, which is required by law
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider all forms of evidence related to residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of residency under the Citizenship Act
